title: ITV in Talks to Sell Networks Arm to Comcast-Owned Sky for $2.1 Billion
description: U.K. broadcaster ITV has confirmed it has received a Â£1.6 billion ($2.1 billion) bid from Comcastâ€™s European pay-TV platform Sky for it media and en
body:
U.K. broadcaster ITV has confirmed it has received a Â£1.6 billion ($2.1 billion) bid from Comcastâ€™s European pay-TV platform Sky for it media and entertainment unit. 

	The shock news â€”Â which landed overnight in the U.K. â€”Â would see Comcast take control of ITVâ€™s linear channels and ITVX streaming business, significantly expanding its foothold in the British TV landscape, having already acquired Sky for around $30 billion in 2018. According to news reports, the bid from Sky centres on the potential creation of a U.K.-focused streaming giant.
	

	In a short statement sent Friday morning, ITVÂ it note â€œthe recentÂ pressÂ speculation and confirms that itÂ is in preliminary discussionsÂ regardingÂ aÂ possibleÂ saleÂ ofÂ itsÂ M&EÂ business to SkyÂ for an enterprise value of Â£1.6bn.â€


	It added: â€œThere can be no certainty as to the terms upon which anyÂ potential saleÂ may be agreed or whether any transaction will take place. A further announcement will be madeÂ in due courseÂ ifÂ appropriate.â€

	The discussions do not include ITVâ€™s production and sales arm, ITV Studios, which has the center of numerous takeover rumours in the last year. RedBird IMI and Banijay are understood to have expressed an interest in the unit. 

	Confirmation of the deal talks came shortly after ITV reported that it would â€œtemporarilyâ€Â shave $46 million from its budgets over the U.K.â€™s â€œsoftening economyâ€ and advertiser uncertainty. It said it expected ad revenues to fall by 9% in the key fourth-quarter period in the lead up to Christmas. 

	ITV shares leaped 18% at the start of trading in London on Friday following news of a potential deal with Sky.

schema.headline: ITV in Talks to Sell Networks Arm to Comcast-Owned Sky for $2.1 Billion

title: Rod Blackhurstâ€™s Horror Film â€˜Dollyâ€™ Lands Distribution Deal With Shudder, Independent Film Company Ahead of AFM (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Shudder and Independent Film Company have closed a deal for Rod Blackhurstâ€˜s horror film â€œDollyâ€ covering North American, U.K., Ireland and Australi
body:
Shudder and Independent Film Company have closed a deal for Rod Blackhurstâ€˜s horror film â€œDollyâ€ covering North American, U.K., Ireland and Australia-New Zealand territories, with plans for a theatrical release next year.

	The film centers on Macy, a young woman fighting to survive after being taken by a monstrous figure intent on raising her as its child. Critics have noted its blend of New French Extremity aesthetics with 1970s American horror sensibilities.
	

	The ensemble includes Fabianne Therese, Seann William Scott, Ethan Suplee, Russ Tiller, Kate Cobb and Michalina Scorzelli. Former NWA TV Champion Max the Impaler, also known as The Non-Binary Nightmare, makes their film debut in the title role.


	The Witchcraft Motion Picture Company production, which earned strong reviews at Fantastic Fest and Sitges Film Festival, marks another genre project for Blackhurst, the Emmy and Critics Choice-nominated filmmaker behind â€œBlood For Dustâ€ and Netflixâ€™s â€œAmanda Knoxâ€ documentary. He also co-wrote Universal and Blumhouseâ€™s â€œNight Swimâ€ with Bryce McGuire.

	Blackhurst wrote the screenplay with Brandon Weavil. Ross Oâ€™Connor produces alongside Noah Lang and Blackhurst through Witchcraft Motion Picture Company, with Set Point Entertainment, Grim Discoveries, Gentile Entertainment Group, Monarque Entertainment and Mama Bear Studios attached. Additional producers include Joseph P. Grano, Betty Tong, Esteban Sanchez, McGuire, Isaiah Smallman and cast members Therese, Scott and Suplee.

	Samuel Zimmerman negotiated the acquisition for Independent Film Company and Shudder, while Blue Finch Films represented the filmmakers.
	

	Steven Schneider, whose credits include â€œParanormal Activityâ€ and â€œInsidious,â€ executive produces with Matt Patterson, Barry Large, Bobby Campbell, Sinan Germirli, Scorzelli, Rudy Mawer, Cam Doody, Jared Houghton, Travis Truitt, Anthony and John Gentile, Mike Chapman, Fatima Hayward, Antonio Dâ€™Intino, Lawrence Dossche and John Neumann.

	â€œâ€˜Dollyâ€™ is a grotesque, beautiful backwoods nightmare,â€ said Zimmerman, senior VP of programming and acquisitions. â€œRod Blackhurst and team transcend their influences to create a beguiling, terrifying new monster; one to love and definitely fear.â€

	â€œâ€˜Dollyâ€™ is both the exact kind of relentless uncompromising genre filmmaking we grew up loving and a testament to what Witchcraft as a studio understands is possible and most important right now; creating original IP and making films that audiences want,â€ added Blackhurst. â€œTruly independent, thematically rich, and created with care and craft. â€˜Dollyâ€™ is here to stay and we are excited for everyone to see the first chapter in an expansive horrifying universe.â€

	Witchcraft Motion Picture Companyâ€™s slate includes Amblinâ€™s â€œThe White Room,â€ Carter Smithâ€™s â€œSwallowed,â€ Peacock series â€œJohn Wayne Gacy: The Devil in Disguiseâ€ and Independent Spirit Award nominee â€œThis is Not a War Story.â€ The company is prepping Blackhurstâ€™s action thriller â€œDie By Nightâ€ while completing post-production on sci-fi film â€œInto the Sky,â€ starring Sam Richardson and David Cross, and drama â€œRuby Road,â€ executive produced by Rosario Dawson.

	Blue Finchâ€™s international lineup includes Fantasia selections â€œHellcatâ€ and â€œHold The Fort,â€ plus horror sci-fi â€œAffectionâ€ with Jessica Rothe.

schema.headline: Rod Blackhurstâ€™s Horror Film â€˜Dollyâ€™ Lands Distribution Deal With Shudder, Independent Film Company Ahead of AFM (EXCLUSIVE)

title: â€˜Predator: Badlands,â€™ â€˜Peaky Blinders,â€™ â€˜The Bride!â€™ All Harness France VFX Expertise
description: Franceâ€™s vibrant VFX sector now stands at the forefront of the countryâ€™s broader push to strengthen its global production appeal, reflecting a natio
body:
Franceâ€™s vibrant VFX sector now stands at the forefront of the countryâ€™s broader push to strengthen its global production appeal, reflecting a national strategy that has championed the craft ever since the 2020 revision of the Tax Rebate for International Production (TRIP). 

	That update introduced a 10% bonus on all eligible expenses for productions spending over $2.3 million with local VFX houses. Five years on, the incentive has proven transformative, driving studio expansion, nurturing talent and attracting a steady stream of high-profile international projects to French soil.
	

	Today, the sector has reached maturity â€” and with maturity comes resilience. The unexpected collapse of Technicolor triggered layoffs and production disruptions, while a broader post-pandemic slowdown has seen commissions drop nearly 30%. With AI disruption and studio consolidation looming, growth increasingly depends on adaptability.


	â€œFlexibility, agility and teamwork define the new business model,â€ says the Yard founder and CEO Laurens Ehrmann. â€œOur midsize structure offers a real advantage. Clients know their projects matter, that theyâ€™ll get an A-team, and that weâ€™ll always respond quickly.â€

	With outposts in Paris, Montpellier and now London â€” a move to access multiple tax credits while staying close to partners like Amazon and Netflix â€” the Yard has tied its expansion directly to relationship management.

	Case in point: after working on 2019â€™s â€œFord v Ferrari,â€ the Yard maintained strong ties with the projectâ€™s VFX supervisor, who later entrusted them with advanced creature work on this yearâ€™s â€œPredator: Badlands.â€ Tasked with a milestone sequence, the studio built an animation, character, creature and digidouble pipeline from scratch, handling 120 complex shots and creating a robust toolset for future creature FX.
	

	â€œWorking on creatures is one of the most complex parts of VFX,â€ Ehrmann explains. â€œMastering it allows you to bid on entire sequences with vast environments and complex characters, now positioning us as a tier-one VFX company.â€



	

									Netflix
	





	

					Parisâ€™ One of Us is handling work on upcoming features â€œThe Bride!â€ and â€œPeaky Blinders: The Immortal Manâ€
	



	Executives from VFX studio One of Us describe their work on 2024â€™s â€œDamselâ€ as similarly transformative. The studio delivered over 400 shots, including 250 featuring a fully realized, emotive dragon, with the rest dedicated to large-scale destruction and fully 3D environments. Splitting the work between outposts in London and Paris, the studioâ€™s teams collaborated seamlessly, emerging from this trial-by-fire with cost-saving insights.

	â€œGetting involved early is critical,â€ says Emmanuel Pichereau, CCO of One of Us. â€œIt allows us to plan strategically, reduce shot counts, control costs and, most importantly, align with the filmâ€™s storytelling from the very beginning when changes are still flexible.â€

	The studio is applying this philosophy to upcoming projects like â€œThe Bride!â€ and â€œPeaky Blinders: The Immortal Man.â€ For both, the team is working from its Paris office to qualify for the full French tax rebate, crafting visual effects designed to be seamless rather than showy.

	â€œWe want to blend into these worlds,â€ says CEO Rachael Penfold. â€œWeâ€™re there to serve the story and realize the filmmakersâ€™ vision, not to show off. The best visual effect is often the one you never notice.â€

	But Penfold is happy to tout the French value proposition â€” and she recently traveled to Los Angeles to championed Gallic talent at industry sessions and case studies.

	â€œThe French film industry is mature, and its talent is often immersed in a culture of great filmmaking, not just trained on specific software,â€ Penfold says. â€œThe emphasis is cultural â€” itâ€™s about artistic problem-solving and craftsmanship. While some focus on technical details, French artists tend to take a more holistic, well-rounded view. That mindset brings added value to every project.â€

schema.headline: â€˜Predator: Badlands,â€™ â€˜Peaky Blinders,â€™ â€˜The Bride!â€™ All Harness France VFX Expertise

title: Thai Girlsâ€™ Love Drama â€˜Love Designâ€™ Acquired by Cappu Films at Taiwan Creative Content Fest (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Hong Kong sales company Cappu Films has picked up Thai Girlsâ€™ Love series â€œLove Designâ€ and is introducing the title to buyers at the Taiwan Creativ
body:
Hong Kong sales company Cappu Films has picked up Thai Girlsâ€™ Love series â€œLove Designâ€ and is introducing the title to buyers at the Taiwan Creative Content Fest (TCCF), which is currently taking place.

	GL and BL (Boysâ€™ Love) series, which center on same-sex romantic relationships, have become a popular genre across Asia, with Thailand emerging as a major production hub for such content.


	Under the arrangement, Cappu Films and VelCurve Studio â€” the production company behind the sci-fi film â€œUranus 2324â€ â€” will jointly handle international sales for Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Vietnam, North America, Latin America and Singapore.
	

	Helmed by Fuse Kittisak Cheewasatjasakun, the series follows two female architects, portrayed by Kao Supassara Thanachart and Jane Methika Jiranorraphat, whose romantic relationship deteriorates into professional animosity after one uses the otherâ€™s designs in a competition without permission.


	The show debuted Oct. 2 with weekly Thursday releases. Thailandâ€™s Channel 3 is airing an eight-episode version, while Tencentâ€™s WeTV platform carries an extended cut with 10 episodes. Fan events for the final two episodes are planned for early December 2025.

	Keetawat Chinnakote, CEO and executive producer at VelCurve Studio, and Janice Woo, founder and head of sales at Cappu Films, negotiated the agreement.

	â€œâ€˜Love Designâ€™ is a GL series that tells the story of the architecture profession â€” exploring both the challenges of work and the romantic relationships of its characters,â€ said Keetawat. â€œIt stars the talented Kao Supassara and Jane Methika, alongside promising newcomers Friend Tofan and Palm Paramee. Produced by VelCurve Studio, the series is crafted with a strong commitment to high production standards and storytelling that allows global audiences to easily understand and connect with its context and emotions.â€
	

	He characterized the series as Thai soft power content that showcases the countryâ€™s creative capabilities internationally, noting his hopes for global audience support through the Cappu Films partnership.

	â€œAt Cappu Films, we are passionate about bringing distinctive Asian stories with global resonance to audiences worldwide,â€ said Woo. â€œâ€˜Love Designâ€™ is a bold and emotionally layered GL series that combines romance, rivalry, and ambition in a fresh way. Partnering with VelCurve Studio allows us to champion diverse storytelling while tapping into the phenomenal energy of the GL fan community across Asia and beyond.â€

	Cappu Films handles international sales for emerging directors and commercial genre content. The companyâ€™s TCCF slate features the Busan Vision competition winner â€œMalikaâ€ from Kazakhstan, the action-thriller â€œFox Huntâ€ with Tony Leung Chiu-wai and Olga Kurylenko, Josh Radnorâ€™s â€œAll Happy Families,â€ the Karlovy Vary entry â€œPromise, Iâ€™ll Be Fineâ€ from Aerofilms/Filmtopia, and the Chinese action title â€œAssassin,â€ which Film Movementâ€™s Omnibus Entertainment label will distribute in North America.

	VelCurve Studioâ€™s previous work includes â€œUranus 2324,â€ which Netflix acquired for its streaming service throughout Southeast Asia, covering Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei, Cambodia, Laos, East Timor, Vietnam, the Philippines, Myanmar and Indonesia.

schema.headline: Thai Girlsâ€™ Love Drama â€˜Love Designâ€™ Acquired by Cappu Films at Taiwan Creative Content Fest (EXCLUSIVE)

title: â€˜Tyler Perryâ€™s Finding Joyâ€™ Review: A Designer and a Dreamboat Recluse Get Snowbound in a Cabin in Perryâ€™s Treacly Holiday Romance
description: One of the defining qualities of Tyler Perryâ€™s movies â€” itâ€™s what keeps you watching but also what can make them, on occasion, seem borderline loopy
body:
One of the defining qualities of Tyler Perryâ€™s movies â€” itâ€™s what keeps you watching but also what can make them, on occasion, seem borderline loopy â€” is the wild mix of tones, sort of like mood swings. Perryâ€™s films can lurch from romance to madcap Madea comedy to skeletons-in-the-closet family drama and backâ€¦all in the space of 20 minutes. Recent years have seen him growing as a filmmaker (the complex historical fable â€œA Jazzmanâ€™s Blues,â€ the wartime drama â€œThe Six Triple Eightâ€), but â€œTyler Perryâ€™s Finding Joyâ€ is a throwback, and not in a good way. Itâ€™s Perryâ€™s version of a holiday movie and a connect-the-dots love story, but itâ€™s clichÃ©-driven in such a minimal way that it almost makes you yearn for the Perry movies that can feel like a long night of channel surfing all rolled into one.
	

	â€œFinding Joyâ€ is basically a two-hander that sets itself up when Joy (Shannon Thornton), an aspiring New York fashion designer, winds up driving through a Colorado blizzard, at which point she and her stalled car plunge through the ice. The next things she knows, she wakes up, warm and dry, in a remote cabin thatâ€™s the home of Ridge (Tosin Morohunfola), one of Perryâ€™s Noble Rugged Deep-Voiced Dreamboats Who Could Be Your Salvation.


	He was out hunting and rescued her (how that happened isnâ€™t clear â€” the last we saw she was 20 feet under the icy water). Okay, heâ€™s a little unfriendly at first. But heâ€™s ripped, heâ€™s handsome, heâ€™s a stoic gentleman who, in his beard and flannel shirt, looks like (in Joyâ€™s words) a â€œBlack lumberjack.â€ And the movie, with these two sexy people sparring for about 10 minutes, only to settle their differences over whiskey before a roaring fire in a snowbound cabin that looks like a vacation hideaway, has an unironic romance-novel baby-itâ€™s-cold-outside vibe of old-school desert-island love. Theyâ€™ll wait out the storm, which might take a week, and heâ€™ll drive her in his truck the 12 miles down the mountain. But itâ€™s beyond obvious where this is all going, and thatâ€™s kind of a dramatic problem. Weâ€™re simply waiting for the ice â€” outside and between them â€” to thaw.Â Â  Â 
	

	How did Joy nearly die in the wilderness of Colorado, a place that, in a joke the film keeps repeating, is almost all white people? The early scenes introduce her as a gifted designer who, despite her beauty and charisma, allows herself to be a doormat in both career and love. Pat-Treek (Eric Stanton Betts), the head of the label she works for, is a disdainful cad who rips off her colorful designs from years before. And she keeps dating men who donâ€™t love her. Thatâ€™s why she follows Colton (Aaron Oâ€™Connell) to his familyâ€™s house in Colorado, thinking that this amiable Ken doll likes her, only to learn that heâ€™s engaged and that he wants her to be the equivalent of his best man.

	But once Joy gets rescued and settles into Ridgeâ€™s small warm rosy candle-lit cabin, the filmâ€™s only dramatic question is: Why is he living like the Unabomber, cooking his rabbit stew in the middle of nowhere, without even a cell phone or radio? (There are tender reasons why, most of them hinging on how devoted he was to his late mother.) The two are united by Perry- esque symmetries. Both are still recovering from relationships that ended in their partnersâ€™ infidelity. And his motherâ€™s name wasâ€¦Joy.

	â€œFinding Joyâ€ is no comedy, but Joyâ€™s friends back in New York, the stoner Littia (Inayah) and the harder-bitten Ashley (Brittany S. Hall), lighten the proceedings a bit, and thereâ€™s one rom-com moment. Joy goes to the frozen outhouse, sits on the wet toilet seat, and sticks to it like the kidâ€™s tongue sticking to a pole in â€œA Christmas Story.â€ So Ridge has to come in there, while her pants are down, and pull her off the seat before she freezes to death. Yet the only real chuckles I got from â€œFinding Joyâ€ were the unintentional kind â€” like in response to the grand reversal of fortune that happens to Joy once she returns to work. Itâ€™s the stuff of fairy tales, but a romantic fairy tale can carry you away, or it can merely play, as it does here, like the adult version of kidsâ€™ stuff.

schema.headline: â€˜Tyler Perryâ€™s Finding Joyâ€™ Review: A Designer and a Dreamboat Recluse Get Snowbound in a Cabin in Perryâ€™s Treacly Holiday Romance

title: Radhika Apte, Manish Malhotra, Tisca Chopraâ€™s â€˜Saali Mohabbatâ€™ Sets ZEE5 Debut (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Tisca Chopraâ€™s directorial debut feature â€œSaali Mohabbatâ€ is set to premiere on Indian streaming platform ZEE5 later this year, following festival r
body:
Tisca Chopraâ€™s directorial debut feature â€œSaali Mohabbatâ€ is set to premiere on Indian streaming platform ZEE5 later this year, following festival runs at IFFI Goa and the Chicago South Asian Film Festival.

	The film centers on Smita, a small-town housewife whose seemingly ordinary life unravels into a narrative exploring infidelity, deceit and moral ambiguity.

	The thriller-drama stars Radhika Apte, Divyendu Sharma, Anurag Kashyap, Anshumaan Pushkar, Sauraseni Maitra and Sharat Saxena. The film marks a reunion for Apte with ZEE5 after her previous platform appearance in â€œMrs. Undercover.â€
	

	â€œSaali Mohabbatâ€ is produced by Jio Studios and Manish Malhotraâ€˜s Stage5 Production, marking the celebrated fashion designerâ€™s digital debut as a producer. The project represents ZEE5â€™s third collaboration with Jio Studios, following â€œHisaab Barabarâ€ and â€œMrs.,â€ which starred R. Madhavan and Sanya Malhotra, respectively, as well as â€œBhagwatâ€ featuring Arshad Warsi and Jitendra Kumar.

	â€œIâ€™ve always been fascinated by the quiet tensions that exist beneath the surface of relationships â€” the invisible power struggles, the unspoken expectations, the ways in which love can transform into something darker,â€ Chopra said. â€œThis film explores those fragile boundaries â€” of trust, betrayal, and identity â€” but through a deeply female perspective.â€

	Kaveri Das, business head of Hindi ZEE5, added: â€œWith â€˜Saali Mohabbat,â€™ weâ€™re thrilled to present a thriller thatâ€™s not just about suspense, but about the intricate emotions that drive human choices.â€ 

	Jyoti Deshpande, president of Jio Studios, characterized the film as â€œan ingeniously crafted thriller that marks our proud collaboration with producer Manish Malhotra, who seamlessly extends his creative brilliance from fashion to film.â€
	

	Malhotra explained that Stage5 Production was established to support original stories with strong craft. â€œThis project has been built with deep involvement at every stage â€” from development to the final cut â€” because at Stage5, we donâ€™t just produce films, we stand by them,â€ he said. â€œEvery creative and strategic decision has been shaped with purpose, rigour, and responsibility.â€

	The producer noted the film features â€œan ensemble of exceptionally talented actors, each bringing a distinct rhythm, restraint, and truth to their characters â€” the kind of performances that donâ€™t speak loudly but linger.â€

	Chopra credited Malhotra with providing crucial early support for the project. â€œManishâ€™s response â€” just three minutes into the narration â€” gave me the conviction that this story had found its right home,â€ she said. â€œHe and his team supported the film not just with resources, but with genuine artistic trust and emotional understanding, allowing it to retain its raw, unpolished honesty.â€

	The director described the filmmaking experience as â€œboth terrifying and liberating â€” terrifying because it demanded emotional vulnerability, and liberating because it allowed me to step outside the boundaries women filmmakers are so often placed within.â€

	ZEE5 serves 190-plus countries with a language-first platform approach, delivering content in seven languages: Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, Bengali, Malayalam, Kannada and Marathi.

schema.headline: Radhika Apte, Manish Malhotra, Tisca Chopraâ€™s â€˜Saali Mohabbatâ€™ Sets ZEE5 Debut (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo Do Barbra Streisand and Judy Garland Proud With â€˜Happyâ€™ Duet on â€˜Wickedâ€™ TV Special: The History Behind the Mellifluous Mashup
description: For nearly the entirety of the â€œWicked: One Wonderful Nightâ€Â TV special, which aired on NBC Thursday night, the performances were focused on Stephen
body:
For nearly the entirety of the â€œWicked: One Wonderful Nightâ€Â TV special, which aired on NBC Thursday night, the performances were focused on Stephen Schwartzâ€™s songs from the two â€œWickedâ€ movies. But for the two-hour showâ€™s climax, stars Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo veered deliciously off-topic to cover a medley of songs first made famous 62 years ago by Barbra Streisand and Judy Garland.

	Some younger viewers may have been initially puzzled by the mashup, but fans of a certain age, or of a certain show-tune leaning, got it from the very first bar, or might have even dared to anticipate it when Erivo and Grande sat down on stools, side by side. It was the pairing of two distinct standards that both date back nearly a hundred years, â€œGet Happyâ€ and â€œHappy Days Are Here Again.â€ The two classics have come to be conjoined in some peopleâ€™s minds, but that is only because they were first sung that way by Garland and Streisand on a legendary episode of â€œThe Judy Garland Showâ€ in 1963.
	




Cynthia Erivo & Ariana Grande singing â€œGet Happy/Happy Days Are Here Againâ€This arrangement was inspired by Barbra Streisand & Judy Garlandâ€™s performance in 1963.  pic.twitter.com/uLNyXRrlKZâ€” Wicked Updates ğŸ§¹ (@wicked_updates) November 7, 2025


	The Judy/Barbra performance became the stuff of legend partly because it captured two legends at opposite ends of their careers. Streisand, then 21, was not only far from a superstar but hadnâ€™t even done â€œFunny Girlâ€ on Broadway yet â€” although she had earlier that year released her debut LP, â€œThe Streisand Album,â€ which had as its Side 2 leadoff number â€œHappy Days Are Here Again.â€ That 1929 tune (written by Milton Ager and Jack Yellen) has remained a staple of her concerts (minus duets or interpolations) right up through her last tour in 2019.
	

	Garland was also singing a signature song for her half of the entwined duet â€” which was reportedly her idea, to jazz up the special. â€œGet Happy,â€ originally penned in 1930 (by Harold Arlen and Ted Koehler), was a pseudo-gospel number she popularized in the 1950 MGM musical â€œSummer Stockâ€ and continued to sing through the end of her life. Then 41, Garland was considered on the professional decline and was six years away from the end of her life when she personally brought in the nascent upstart for several numbers on the Oct. 6, 1963 episode of her weekly variety show.

	This particular mashup hardly counts as culturally ubiquitous in 2025. But Grande and Erivo are far from the first to revive it in the modern era, as the medley continues to have cachet among musical theater actors looking for an impressive way to pair up. 

	Erivo herself has had some practice at it: She previously did it in tandem with Ben Platt one night during his London concert run in 2024. Scroll down to see video of the Erivo/Platt duet, along with other covers. (Thereâ€™s no apparent record of Grande having sung it with anyone before; she has sung with Streisand both live and on record, but they missed an opportunity in not attempting the tune together.)




	If the doubled-up cover feels somewhat familiar to a somewhat younger generation, it may be because it did get significant exposure through an episode of â€œGleeâ€ from that showâ€™s second season in 2011, as Lea Michele and Chris Coffer teamed up side by side â€” with Micheleâ€™s costuming obviously designed to resemble Streisandâ€™s from 1963.




	Other duets that can be seen or heard in clips below include Rufus Wainwright with Kristin Chenoweth; Billy Porter with Cyndi Lauper; Audra McDonald with Patti LuPone â€” on repeated occasions over the years! (we know, we know); and, going back to 1964, Garland with her daughter, Liza Minnelli.







	In the fall of 1963, Garland was determined to have Streisand on her show after catching her at the the Cocoanut Grove in the summer. Norman Jewison, later to be a famous feature helmer, was the director of the Streisand episode (which also featured Ethel Merman and the Smothers Brothers). Mel TormÃ© was employed to work on special musical material for the series, and he offered backstory for the duet in his bookÂ â€œThe Other Side of the Rainbow; With Judy Garland on the Dawn Patrol.â€ There, he wrote that Garland summoned him to her dressing room and suggested an inspired idea for the show, playing Streisandâ€™s LP version of â€œHappy Days Are Here Againâ€ while singing a counter-melody of â€œGet Happy.â€
	

	Wrote TormÃ©: â€œThe result was electrifying, one of those chance discoveries in which two great songs jell into one extraspecial opus.â€

	That and the other performances by Streisand mightily impressed CBS executives, regardless of whether the guest was yet a major star at the time. They bumped the episode up ahead of some others that had already been filmed, and it aired just two days after it was recorded, on Oct. 6, 1963.

	A half-century or more later, it continued to impress. Profiling Streisand for the New York Times in 2016, the paperâ€™s theater critic, Ben Brantley, wrote: â€œEach interpreted an upbeat song with a big, trumpeting voice that nonetheless hinted at a small, solitary figure within. Happiness, as hymned in these renditions, would never be won easily. You can find thatÂ video on YouTube, and it is impossible to watch it without shivering.â€

	Talking with Brantley, Streisand said of Garland, â€œAfterward, she used to visit me and give me advice. She came to my apartment in New York, and she said to me, â€˜Donâ€™t let them do to you what they did to me.â€™ I didnâ€™t know what she meant then. I was just getting started.â€

	In a 2005 interview with Diane Sawyer, Streisand said that Garland â€œwas great. She was wonderful. Loved her â€¦ I was very secure then. I was only 21, I think. I wasnâ€™t afraid of failure or anything. But it was interesting to see someone who was so great and so famous and so gifted â€¦ She was drinking Liebfraumilch â€” you know, a white wine â€” and her hands were shaking and she was holding onto me. I thought, what was this about? As one grows older, what is this fear? And I understand it now.â€

	Streisand received her first Emmy nomination for the episode, in the category of Outstanding Performance in a Variety or Musical Program.

	Few contemporary singers would have the nerve to recreate a moment so very tagged to two of the greatest of the 20th century (or in Streisandâ€™s case, 20th going on 21st), but few enjoy the good will, on top of the chops, that Erivo and Grande have going into the second and final part of the filmic â€œWickedâ€ franchise. If it turns out to be happy days for them at the Oscars, their ability to nail a tricky duet classic might have contributed just a little, if clips of the performance become as widely circulated as expected.
	



	

	



	Meanwhile, letâ€™s hear it for the audience that saw the taping at the Dolby Theatre Sept. 24 and somehow managed to keep the climax under wraps even on social media until now. EIther that, or they were too young to recognize its significanceâ€¦ Nah, letâ€™s go with discretion.

	Here are a few of the other versions rendered from over the years, including another of the many, many times LuPone and McDonald did it over a period of at least a decade and a half, long before the former called the latter â€œnot a friendâ€ earlier this year. Perhaps this revival of the medley will inspire them to hold space for one another yet again.

schema.headline: Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo Do Barbra Streisand and Judy Garland Proud With â€˜Happyâ€™ Duet on â€˜Wickedâ€™ TV Special: The History Behind the Mellifluous Mashup

title: Teen Horror â€˜Bali Demons,â€™ Robert Gwisdek Drama, â€˜Because of Youâ€™ Series, â€˜Einsteinâ€™ AI Project on Traumfabrik Babelsberg Slate (EXCLUSIVE)
description: German production company Traumfabrik Babelsberg is doubling down on its investment in international moviemaking, with a burgeoning slate of product
body:
German production company Traumfabrik Babelsberg is doubling down on its investment in international moviemaking, with a burgeoning slate of productions with global appeal in the works, as well as its first series.

	The company was founded in 2017 by Tom Zickler and Christoph Fisser, when the latter also was managing director of Babelsberg, the major film studios on the edge of Berlin, which was its parent company. Zickler was best known as the producer of German star Til Schweigerâ€™s films up until 2016. The company takes its name from its first film, 2019â€™s â€œTraumfabrik,â€ which translates as â€œDreamfactory.â€ Sadly, Zickler died of cancer in 2019 at the age of 55.
	

	Following Fisserâ€™s departure from Babelsberg at the beginning of last year, Traumfabrik Babelsberg was reborn as an independent entity, led by Fisser and Sebastian Fruner, who has been at the company since it began. They were then joined by Konstantin Mayer, the former COO at Veronica Ferresâ€™ company, Construction Film Produktion. Since then, the company has been reinvigorated, and has a number of high-profile projects on its books.


	Talking to Variety, Fruner said that when he met Mayer in Cannes it was a â€œmatch made in heavenâ€ as the two producers had a similar desire to make ambitious projects with the potential to find an international audience.

	One film has already wrapped production and post. It is a theatrical feature produced with Kreisfilm, which is directed by Robert Gwisdek and stars Christian Friedel, best known for â€œThe Zone of Interestâ€ and â€œThe White Lotus,â€ and Corinna Harfouch, whose credits include â€œDownfallâ€ and â€œNever Look Away.â€
	

	The film, which is at present untitled, is described as a â€œphilosophical drama.â€ It is, in part, inspired by the death of Robert Gwisdekâ€™s father, which is intriguing as Harfouch is the directorâ€™s mother. The film will be released next year and Fruner hopes itâ€™ll have a strong festival run, with an eye to a premiere at Berlin or Cannes. Discussions with potential German distributors are ongoing.

	The film marks the beginning of a long-term collaboration with Kreisfilm, according to Traumfabrik Babelsberg, with two additional major international films now being packaged and seeking financing.

	Another project is teen horror film â€œBali Demons,â€ which is in development. It is based on an idea by Mayer, with the script written by Sophia Vester. The film is â€œabout the conflict between cultural tradition and mass tourism,â€ Mayer says. He notes that in the past year or so this has become a bigger issue with public protests against mass tourism in several tourism hotspots, such as Venice, Majorca and Barcelona.

	Mayer says the film is intended to be the first in a franchise, and will be followed by â€œVenice Demonsâ€ and â€œTokyo Demons.â€ He says it is about â€œtourists behaving badly in holy places,â€ adding, â€œNobody would go in a bikini in a church in Munich and have sex there but in Bali that happens all the time. It is disrespectful to their culture, their ancient tradition.â€

	In the film, â€œthereâ€™s a group of tourists, young, beautiful people,â€ he says. â€œI call this â€˜Screamâ€™ on Bali, or â€˜Screamâ€™ in exotic places, because one after another gets killed by a figure who has a traditional mask on.â€ Mayer adds, â€œThe people start thinking, â€˜Maybe the demons want to have their island back.â€™â€

	He says that some people have described it as a cross between â€œScreamâ€ and â€œMidsommar.â€

	It stars Indonesian singer Adriana Raisa, German actress Helena Zengel (â€œThe Legend of Ochi,â€ â€œNews of the World,â€ â€œSystem Crasherâ€) and U.S. actor Gianni Paolo (â€œMa,â€ â€œPowerâ€). A major U.S. star and the director will be revealed soon.

	The film is likely to shoot next year in Bali and is produced in association with Bo Holmgreen of Viking Sunset Studios and Orlando Bassi of Movie Studios Bali.
	

	Traumfabrik Babelsberg is also planning to produce its first series, young adult romance â€œBecause of You,â€ based on Nadine Kergerâ€™s bestselling novels of the same name. The showrunner is Martin Schreier, whose â€œMaxton Hallâ€ became the most successful non-U.S. Prime Original worldwide. The series is set at a boat club on Malta, where they plan to shoot in March 2027, with backing from German public broadcaster SWR.

	The company is also producing crime comedy â€œHimmel, Herrgott, Hirschgeweih,â€ which is set in Bavaria, Southern Germany. It has been developed with German distributor Tobis Film and will receive a theatrical release. It is envisioned as a franchise.

	Traumfabrik Babelsberg is also developing a spoof comedy with David Zucker, Mayer says, which will be released worldwide with a yet-to-be announced partner.

	Traumfabrik Babelsberg has also experimented with AI on â€œEinstein â€“ Bringing a Legend Back to Life.â€ Using cutting-edge AI they have brought Einstein back to life, based on a performance by actor Heiner Lauterbach, but using Einsteinâ€™s own words. The film, which is two hours and 22 minutes long, is entirely composed of AI-generated content. It was released on the Meet Your Master platform last month. Traumfabrik Babelsberg is now developing a fiction feature, â€œEinstein,â€ using the same technology.

schema.headline: Teen Horror â€˜Bali Demons,â€™ Robert Gwisdek Drama, â€˜Because of Youâ€™ Series, â€˜Einsteinâ€™ AI Project on Traumfabrik Babelsberg Slate (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Manoj Bajpayee Returns as Hunted Spy in Prime Videoâ€™s â€˜The Family Manâ€™ Season 3 Trailer (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Prime Video has unveiled the trailer for the third season of its hit spy-thriller series â€œThe Family Man,â€ with Manoj Bajpayeeâ€˜s iconic character Sr
body:
Prime Video has unveiled the trailer for the third season of its hit spy-thriller series â€œThe Family Man,â€ with Manoj Bajpayeeâ€˜s iconic character Srikant Tiwari now finding himself on the run from both new adversaries and his own intelligence unit.

	The trailer was unveiled at a fan and media event in Mumbai on Friday, previewing the series created by Raj & DK under their D2R Films banner. Season 3 sees Srikant racing against time to protect himself, his family and the nation from an imminent threat, with the hunter now becoming the hunted.
	

	â€œFor the past four years, fans have hounded me with the question, â€˜When is Srikant Tiwari coming?â€™ And we finally have the answer with a new season thatâ€™s not only bigger, bolder, and more exciting but also raises the stakes higher than ever for Srikant, as he finds himself cornered with no respite in sight,â€ said Bajpayee. â€œThanks to Raj and DKâ€™s vision and masterful storytelling, and the continued support of Prime Video, â€˜The Family Manâ€™ has become one of the most-loved Indian series.â€


	The latest season introduces two formidable new adversaries: Rukma, played by Jaideep Ahlawat (â€œPaatal Lokâ€), and Meera, portrayed by Nimrat Kaur (â€œThe Lunchboxâ€). 

	â€œI have always admired Raj and DK for their creative abilities and bringing to life a series like â€˜The Family Man,â€™ which has become one of the most watched and loved Indian series all over the world, and I am thrilled to be a part of the latest season,â€ said Ahlawat. â€œWithout giving away much about my character, I am certain that everyone will be surprised to see me portraying this role.â€
	

	The series is written by Raj, DK and Suman Kumar, featuring dialogues by Sumit Arora. Raj & DK direct alongside Suman Kumar and Tusshar Seyth, who join as directors for Season 3.

	Kaur, who described herself as a fan of the series since Season 1, called joining the show â€œa dream come true.â€ â€œPlaying Meera was both thrilling and challenging, as I had to match the caliber and performative brilliance of Manoj and Jaideep,â€ she said. â€œAnd the way Raj, DK, and Suman have crafted the story with its rich characters and unpredictable twists, I believe audiences will want to binge the new season in one go.â€

	The explosive trailer showcases the seriesâ€™ signature elements including witty dialogues, high-octane action, thrilling chases and the blurred lines between Srikantâ€™s personal and professional life. In Season 3, Srikant must navigate life on the run with his family while being pursued by TASC, his own intelligence unit, in addition to the new threats.

	â€œSeason 3 of â€˜The Family Manâ€™ turns Srikantâ€™s covert professional and fragile personal life upside down, as he is forced to go on the run with his family while facing an even more alarming threat in Rukma and Meera,â€ said creators, directors and writers Raj & DK. â€œBoth Jaideep and Nimrat are the perfect choice, as actors and personalities to embody these dynamic and menacing foes, testing not only Srikantâ€™s grit and resolve but also his commitment to his family and his nation. Taking the story several notches higher the new season will grip audiences with its edge-of-the-seat tension and nail-biting moments as they witness their favorite spy navigating uncharted territories and peril.â€

	Returning cast members include Sharib Hashmi as J.K. Talpade, Priyamani as Suchitra Tiwari, Ashlesha Thakur as Dhriti Tiwari, Vedant Sinha as Atharv Tiwari, Shreya Dhanwanthary as Zoya and Gul Panag as Saloni.

	â€œThe Family Manâ€ Season 3 will premiere exclusively on Prime Video on Nov. 21 in India and over 240 countries and territories worldwide.

	Watch the trailer here:

schema.headline: Manoj Bajpayee Returns as Hunted Spy in Prime Videoâ€™s â€˜The Family Manâ€™ Season 3 Trailer (EXCLUSIVE)

title: â€˜Female Teacher: Forbidden Sexâ€™ Among Selections as Rotterdam Spotlights Japanâ€™s V-Cinema Movement
description: The International Film Festival Rotterdam (IFFR) has unveiled its second Focus program for the 55th edition, turning the spotlight on Japanâ€™s V-Cine
body:
The International Film Festival Rotterdam (IFFR) has unveiled its second Focus program for the 55th edition, turning the spotlight on Japanâ€™s V-Cinema â€” the direct-to-video movement that exploded in the late 1980s and profoundly shaped the countryâ€™s contemporary film culture. 

	The section, curated by Tom Mes, will run as part of the festivalâ€™s 2026 edition from Jan. 29 to Feb. 8.


	Originating with Toeiâ€™s â€œCrime Hunter: Bullets of Rageâ€ (1989), V-Cinema responded to Japanâ€™s booming home video market by producing films that bypassed theaters entirely. The low-budget, high-speed production model gave directors unprecedented creative freedom, birthing a generation of filmmakers who went on to define modern Japanese cinema â€” including Miike Takashi, Nakata Hideo, Kurosawa Kiyoshi and Aoyama Shinji.
	

	IFFRâ€™s V-Cinema Focus will showcase a range of Toei titles, among them the â€œCrime Hunterâ€ trilogy â€” â€œCrime Hunter: Bullets of Rage,â€ â€œCrime Hunter 2: Bullets of Betrayalâ€ and â€œCrime Hunter 3: Killing Bullet.â€ The lineup also features Nakataâ€™s debut feature â€œFemale Teacher: Forbidden Sex,â€ the psychological noir â€œBetrayal Tomorrow,â€ and the cult action thriller â€œXX Beautiful Weapon.â€


	The program expands beyond Toei to highlight the anarchic spirit and genre experimentation that defined the movement. Among the selections are the ghostly anthology â€œScary True Stories: Second Night,â€ the eerie found-footage investigation â€œPsychic Vision: Jaganrei,â€ and Miikeâ€™s hyperviolent â€œFudoh: The New Generation.â€ Other highlights include the surreal gangland fable â€œTuff: Part I,â€ Kurosawaâ€™s deadpan yakuza comedy â€œSuit Yourself or Shoot Yourself!! VI: The Hero,â€ Aoyamaâ€™s archetypal action drama â€œA Weapon in My Heart,â€ and â€œThe King of Minami,â€ about a loan shark aiding small business owners.
	

	â€œV-Cinema offered filmmakers the space to take risks, move fast and work with a freedom rarely possible within the traditional studio system,â€ said IFFR festival director Vanja Kaludjercic. â€œWhat emerged was a wild and inventive cinema embracing everything from anarchic yakuza tales and psycho-horror experiments to surreal hybrid pieces â€” work that still feels electric today.â€

	IFFRâ€™s full 2026 program will be unveiled on Dec. 16.

schema.headline: â€˜Female Teacher: Forbidden Sexâ€™ Among Selections as Rotterdam Spotlights Japanâ€™s V-Cinema Movement

title: David Harbour, Millie Bobby Brown Attend 'Strangers Things' Premiere Amid Drama
description:
David Harbour, Millie Bobby Brown
                          Not So Strange at Premiere ...
body:
David Harbour, Millie Bobby Brown
                          Not So Strange at Premiere ...
                          Amid Bullying, Harassment Claims
                      
                  
                        Published November 6, 2025 7:05 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
          The "Strangers Things" cast got together Thursday night in Los Angeles for the premiere of the Netflix show's final season ... and David Harbour and Millie Bobby Brown were notably seen not only arriving together, but posing for some pics -- amid some serious allegations she reportedly made against him.
      
    
      
      David Harbour and Millie Bobby Brown arrive together for one last Stranger Things premiere ğŸ¥¹ pic.twitter.com/zjzcPi9Zv4â€” Netflix (@netflix) November 7, 2025
              @netflix
          
  
    
          There has been speculation that this occasion would feel sorta strange -- being the premiere comes on the heels of reports about Millie allegedly filing a bullying and harassment complaint against David -- but MBB was all smiles as she is seen being playful with her co-star of now 5 seasons.
      
    
          The actress reportedly filed the alleged complaint before she started filming the final season with David, so one could predict that they would avoid each other at all costs ... but the pair are leaving the rumors in The Upside Down.
      
    
          We reached out to reps for Millie and David ... so far no word back.

          "Pawn Stars" star Rick Harrison is facing heartbreaking news -- his mother, Joanne Harrison, died yesterday, TMZ has learned.

          Weâ€™re told Rickâ€™s keeping things private right now -- understandably so, after losing both parents. His father, Richard Harrison, passed in 2018 from Parkinsonâ€™s disease.

          Rick had been trying to move forward with life -- even recently popping the question to fiancÃ©e Angie Polushkin with a 6.5-carat pear-shaped ring from his own Gold & Silver Pawn Shop.
